metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (leaf area index of Daman Superstation, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Daman superstation in the middle reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 1 to September 20 in 2020. The site (100.376° E, 38.853°N) was located in the maize surface, near Zhangye city in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. There are 6 observation samples, each of which is about 30m×30m in size, and the latitude and longitude are (100.376°E, 38.853°N), (100.377° E, 38.858°N), (100.374°E, 38.855°N), (100.374°E, 38.858°N), (100.371°E, 38.854°N), (100.369°E, 38.854°N). Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The data is obtained from LAINet measurements; the four-steps are performed to obtain LAI: the raw data is light quantum (level 0); the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); further the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the Leaf Area Index (LAI) and how is it measured in the context of hydrometeorological observations?
Definition.Answer: The Leaf Area Index (LAI) is a dimensionless quantity that characterizes plant canopies. In the context of hydrometeorological observations, LAI is measured using a wireless sensor network (LAINet), which collects light data at multiple nodes within each sample area. The data is processed from raw light measurements to calculate daily LAI values, and further refined by identifying and filling invalid values, with a 7-day moving average to minimize weather impact, resulting in a Level3 dataset.

Definition.Question: What are oasis–desert systems and why are they significant in arid and semi-arid regions?
Definition.Answer: Oasis–desert systems are unique ecological landscapes in arid and semi-arid areas, serving as cores for ecological environments and foundations for economic development. They are significant because they maintain ecological stability and agricultural productivity, and are crucial for supporting over 90% of the population in these regions despite comprising less than 10% of the area. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these systems is essential for achieving sustainable development and ecological security.

Definition.Question: What observational methods are used to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Definition.Answer: Observational methods for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems include long-term datasets of fluxes and auxiliary data. Data is collected using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent fluxes, while hydrometeorological data is gathered from automatic weather stations. This data includes parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, temperature, humidity, wind speed, and more, supplemented by vegetation and soil parameters, and is processed for quality control and archiving.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using the LAINet wireless sensor network for leaf area index compare to the eddy covariance system and scintillometer used for energy and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas?
Comparison.Answer: The LAINet wireless sensor network focuses on capturing leaf area index data by automatically acquiring light data at each node and processing it to obtain daily LAI values. In contrast, the eddy covariance system and scintillometer acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data for energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, providing comprehensive insights into energy and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges faced in ecological environment degradation in arid and semiarid areas influence data collection methodologies for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges?
Interpretation.Answer: Ecological degradation challenges such as drying rivers, vegetation loss, and dust storms necessitate robust data collection methods to maintain long-term observations. This includes establishing multiple observation stations and using systems like eddy covariance and scintillometers for detailed flux data, coupled with automatic weather stations for frequent hydrometeorological data collection, addressing the need for comprehensive monitoring in these vulnerable areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the process for using wireless sensor networks to collect and process leaf area index data in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Leaf area index data is collected using the LAINet wireless sensor network, which automatically gathers light data at each node daily. The raw data (Level0) is processed using LAINet software to calculate daily LAI for each node (Level1). Invalid values are identified and filled, and a 7-day moving average is applied to mitigate weather-related fluctuations (Level2). For sub-areas with multiple LAINet nodes, the average of the nodes provides the final observation value (Level3).

The compiled datasets are made available through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in data collection for arid and semiarid regions, particularly in developing sustainable oasis-desert systems, and suggest potential methods to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation challenges such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are prominent in regions like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin. To overcome these challenges, long-term and comprehensive datasets from artificial and natural oasis-desert systems could be valuable. These datasets should include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Utilizing advanced data collection methods such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations can aid in acquiring accurate and consistent data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss potential data collection methods that can be employed to monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods for monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems include using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automatic weather stations can be utilized to observe hydrometeorological data, such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and air temperature and humidity gradients. These stations also measure wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Supplementing these datasets with vegetation and soil parameters can provide a comprehensive understanding of the ecosystem dynamics.
